<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  1. BILATERAL IS ENOUGH                                 â”‚
â”‚     No global consensus needed.                         â”‚
â”‚     Pairwise agreement propagates.                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  2. EVENTUAL CONSISTENCY IS FINE                        â”‚
â”‚     "Will eventually reach common knowledge"            â”‚
â”‚     Temporary divergence is okay.                       â”‚
â”‚     Your waterline shows YOUR view.                     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  3. CHEATING IS A SOCIAL PROBLEM                        â”‚
â”‚     Protocol handles confusion.                         â”‚
â”‚     Attestations handle disagreement.                   â”‚
â”‚     Trust model handles bad actors.                     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  4. RETRY UNTIL ACK                                     â”‚
â”‚     Messages repeated until acknowledged.               â”‚
â”‚     Survives network partitions.                        â”‚
â”‚     Survives device restarts.                           â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  5. SEQUENCE NUMBERS + CONTENT HASH                     â”‚
â”‚     You know what you've sent (seq)                     â”‚
â”‚     You can verify what you receive (hash)              â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

</div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  TRAIL SYNC PROTOCOL                                    â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Layer 0: Transport (WebSocket, HTTP, BLE mesh, etc)    â”‚
â”‚  Layer 1: Message integrity (TLS, signatures)           â”‚
â”‚  Layer 2: SNAP-style bilateral sync                     â”‚
â”‚           - Idempotent ops                              â”‚
â”‚           - ACK/retry until confirmed                   â”‚
â”‚           - Sequence numbers per participant            â”‚
â”‚  Layer 3: Trail semantics                               â”‚
â”‚           - Genesis verification                        â”‚
â”‚           - Op validation (schema, invariants)          â”‚
â”‚           - Causal ordering via prev_ops                â”‚
â”‚  Layer 4: Wellspring meaning                            â”‚
â”‚           - Ops become bubbles, chains, attestations    â”‚
â”‚           - Trust computed from graph                   â”‚
â”‚           - Waterline reflects local view               â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

</div>
:::

This gives us multi-master replication without blockchain, without
central server, with provable provenance. Bush\'s trail-sharing,
implemented on SNAP-style bilateral consensus.

Should I add this to the spec doc, or keep digging into edge cases
first?

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  1. Keif creates thought (bubble in his pod)            â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  2. Keif decides to publish to pool:uk-construction     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  3. Creates chain:                                      â”‚
â”‚     thought â†’ published_to â†’ pool:uk-construction       â”‚
â”‚     attestation: { by: keif, +1.0 }                     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  4. Notifies pool (push or pool pulls)                  â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  5. Pool validates:                                     â”‚
â”‚     - Is keif a member? (check membership chain)        â”‚
â”‚     - Does content meet pool rules?                     â”‚
â”‚     - Spam check, etc.                                  â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  6. Pool attests:                                       â”‚
â”‚     attestation: { by: pool:uk-construction, +1.0,      â”‚
â”‚                    because: [member, valid] }           â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  7. Pool adds to index, appears in feeds                â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  8. Sarah, browsing pool, discovers Keif's thought      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  DISCOVERY = PUBLICATION + POOLS + TRUST                â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Publication:  Chain your thought to a pool             â”‚
â”‚  Pool:         Aggregates, indexes, serves feeds        â”‚
â”‚  Trust:        Pools discovered via web of trust        â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  All expressible as bubbles, chains, attestations.      â”‚
â”‚  No new primitives needed.                              â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Centralization risk:                                   â”‚
â”‚    Pools CAN become powerful (like Mastodon instances)  â”‚
â”‚    Mitigation: easy to create pools, easy to leave      â”‚
â”‚    Your data stays in YOUR pod regardless               â”‚

â”‚                                                         â”‚

â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  CHAIN: sarah â†’ can_write â†’ pool:xyz                    â”‚
â”‚    attestation: { by: admin, +1.0, at: T1 }  â† granted  â”‚
â”‚    attestation: { by: admin, 0.0, at: T2 }   â† revoked  â”‚

â”‚  Permission at time T = latest attestation before T     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  POOL RELATIONSHIPS                                     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  CHAIN: pool:uk-construction â†’ federated_with â†’         â”‚
â”‚         pool:eu-construction                            â”‚
â”‚    attestation: { by: pool:uk (admin), +1.0 }           â”‚
â”‚    attestation: { by: pool:eu (admin), +1.0 }           â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Federation = mutual attestation                        â”‚
â”‚  Both pools agree to share content                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  FEDERATION MODES:                                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Mirror:    All content synced both ways                â”‚
â”‚  Bridge:    Selected content crosses over               â”‚
â”‚  Subscribe: One-way, pool A reads pool B                â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  CHAIN: pool:A â†’ subscribes_to â†’ pool:B                 â”‚
â”‚    attestation: { by: pool:A, +1.0 }                    â”‚

â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  WELLSPRING ETERNAL                                     â”‚
â”‚    Your memory, your knowledge, your trails             â”‚
â”‚    "Where did I learn that?"                            â”‚
â”‚    "Who did I tell?"                                    â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚

â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  WOT                                                    â”‚
â”‚    Group memory, group preferences, group decisions     â”‚
â”‚    "Where shall we go?"                                 â”‚
â”‚    "What does everyone want?"                           â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Personal memory + shared pools = social cognition      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  The "gang" pool IS a shared Wellspring.                â”‚
â”‚  Decisions are just queries with deadlines.             â”‚
â”‚  Preferences are just persistent attestations.          â”‚

â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  ATTESTATION (final)                                    â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  {                                                      â”‚
â”‚    by: identity,                                        â”‚
â”‚    on: bubble,              // what I'm evaluating      â”‚
â”‚    via: aspect_bubble,      // through what lens        â”‚
â”‚    weight: float [-1, +1],  // how much it satisfies    â”‚
â”‚    at: timestamp,                                       â”‚
â”‚    because: [chain_ids],    // evidence (optional)      â”‚
â”‚    sig: signature                                       â”‚
â”‚  }                                                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  ASPECT (bubble with type)                              â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  {                                                      â”‚
â”‚    id: bubble_id,                                       â”‚
â”‚    type: value|preference|need|mood|constraint,         â”‚
â”‚    owner: identity,         // personal or shared       â”‚
â”‚    domain: string,          // food, logistics, social  â”‚
â”‚    decay: duration|none,    // how fast it fades        â”‚
â”‚    ...                                                  â”‚
â”‚  }                                                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  BELIEF (computed)                                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  belief(identity, subject, context, time) =             â”‚
â”‚    aggregate over all attestations by identity on subjectâ”‚
â”‚    weighted by aspect importance in context             â”‚
â”‚    adjusted by decay at time                            â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  AllegroGraph / Oxford Semantic:                        â”‚
â”‚    - Powerful reasoning engines                         â”‚
â”‚    - No data creation story                             â”‚
â”‚    - Enterprise focus (expensive, complex)              â”‚
â”‚    - "Bring your ontology and data"                     â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Wellspring:                                            â”‚
â”‚    - Data EMERGES from behavior                         â”‚
â”‚    - Ontology EMERGES from attestation                  â”‚
â”‚    - Consumer focus (personal, social)                  â”‚
â”‚    - "Just live your life, we'll build the graph"       â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  They need us more than we need them.                   â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Once Wellspring has rich behavioral data:              â”‚
â”‚    - Plug in any reasoning engine                       â”‚
â”‚    - Or build native inference                          â”‚

â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  EMERGENT ONTOLOGY                                      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Principles:                                            â”‚
â”‚    1. Aspects proposed by agent, attested by human      â”‚
â”‚    2. Hierarchy emerges from instance_of attestations   â”‚
â”‚    3. Universal aspects emerge from cross-user patterns â”‚
â”‚    4. Rejection + because teaches the agent             â”‚
â”‚    5. Ontology is data, not schema                      â”‚
â”‚    6. Can export to OWL/RDF for external reasoning      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  Agent proposals are ALWAYS:                            â”‚
â”‚    - Marked as agent-proposed                           â”‚
â”‚    - Surfaced for human review                          â”‚
â”‚    - Not trusted until attested                         â”‚
â”‚    - Learning from rejection as much as acceptance      â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â”‚  The WHY (because chain) is first-class:                â”‚
â”‚    - Acceptance because: [evidence that worked]         â”‚
â”‚    - Rejection because: [why the inference was wrong]   â”‚
â”‚    - Refinement because: [what's actually true]         â”‚
â”‚                                                         â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
```

</div>
:::

The semantic web\'s grave error was assuming humans would do the work.
Wellspring\'s insight: the agent does the work, humans just say
yes/no/why. That\'s sustainable. That\'s how you get a living ontology.
:::

::: {.overflow-x-auto .w-full .px-2 .mb-6}

  ------------------------------- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Bush\'s Memex**               Historical grounding --- we\'re completing an 80-year vision
  **Trails**                      First-class named paths, shareable, multi-master
  **Browser Extension**           Automated trail capture from browsing behavior
  **Sync as Attestation**         SNAP-inspired, no separate protocol layer --- chains all the way down
  **Pool Model**                  Universal primitive --- your pod IS a pool, federation via attestation

  **WOT Integration**             Group consensus as Wellspring application

::: {.standard-markdown .grid-cols-1 .grid .[&_>_*]:min-w-0 .gap-3 .standard-markdown}
Good question. Looking beyond the weight, OWL has several genuinely
useful concepts we could adopt:

**1. Property Characteristics (Relation Types)**

OWL declares properties as transitive, symmetric, inverse, functional.
We have some of this implicitly but could be explicit:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}
::: {.absolute .right-0 .h-8 .px-2 .items-center .inline-flex .z-10}
::: {.relative}
::: {.transition-all .opacity-100 .scale-100 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
RELATION CHARACTERISTICS (could add to Wellspring)

Transitive:    part_of, ancestor_of, contains
               If A part_of B, B part_of C â†’ A part_of C

Symmetric:     sibling_of, colleague_of, related_to
               If A sibling_of B â†’ B sibling_of A

Inverse:       parent_of â†” child_of, employs â†” works_at
               If A parent_of B â†’ B child_of A

Functional:    has_mother (exactly one value)
               If A has_mother B and A has_mother C â†’ B = C
```

</div>
:::

We currently have `vouches`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5
.border-border-300 .text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap
.rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px .text-[0.9rem]},
`supports`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5 .border-border-300
.text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px
.text-[0.9rem]}, `derives_from`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5
.border-border-300 .text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap
.rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px .text-[0.9rem]} but haven\'t declared
their propagation characteristics formally.

**2. Disjointness (Mutual Exclusion)**

OWL can declare \"Person and Company are disjoint\" --- nothing can be
both. We could use this:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}
::: {.absolute .right-0 .h-8 .px-2 .items-center .inline-flex .z-10}
::: {.relative}
::: {.transition-all .opacity-100 .scale-100 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
CHAIN: keif/constraint:vegetarian â†’ disjoint_with â†’ contains_meat
  // Anything attested as vegetarian CANNOT be attested as contains_meat
  // System catches contradiction automatically
```

</div>
:::

Useful for catching inconsistencies in attestations.

**3. Property Chains (Compositional Relations)**

OWL can define: `hasUncle = hasFather âˆ˜ hasBrother`{.bg-text-200/5
.border .border-0.5 .border-border-300 .text-danger-000
.whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px .text-[0.9rem]}. If
you have chains Aâ†’B and Bâ†’C, infer Aâ†’C.

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}
::: {.absolute .right-0 .h-8 .px-2 .items-center .inline-flex .z-10}
::: {.relative}
::: {.transition-all .opacity-100 .scale-100 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
PROPERTY CHAIN:

lives_in_country = lives_in_city âˆ˜ city_in_country

keif â†’ lives_in â†’ Manchester
Manchester â†’ in_country â†’ UK
âˆ´ keif â†’ lives_in_country â†’ UK   (inferred)
```

</div>
:::

This is powerful for automatic chain completion. We could declare these
for inference without storing redundant chains.

**4. Cardinality Constraints**

OWL: \"Person must have exactly 2 biological parents\" or \"Car must
have at least 4 wheels\"

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}
::: {.absolute .right-0 .h-8 .px-2 .items-center .inline-flex .z-10}
::: {.relative}
::: {.transition-all .opacity-100 .scale-100 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
CARDINALITY:

keif/constraint:vegetarian
  min_options: 1  // venue must have at least 1 veggie option
  
family-dinner
  max_cost_per_head: 25  // Â£25 cap
```

</div>
:::

For WOT specifically, this is useful --- \"must have at least N options
satisfying constraint.\"

**5. Open World Assumption**

OWL assumes absence of information â‰  false. This is philosophically
correct and we\'re already doing it (attestation absent â‰  belief
absent), but worth making explicit:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}
::: {.absolute .right-0 .h-8 .px-2 .items-center .inline-flex .z-10}
::: {.relative}
::: {.transition-all .opacity-100 .scale-100 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
WELLSPRING: Open World

No attestation from keif on nandos
  â‰  keif believes 0.0 about nandos
  = keif hasn't expressed belief

This differs from closed-world databases where
  row absent = fact false
```

</div>
:::

**6. Equivalence (Same-As)**

OWL: `owl:sameAs`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5 .border-border-300
.text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px
.text-[0.9rem]} for identity resolution. We started on this with
`resolves_to`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5 .border-border-300
.text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px
.text-[0.9rem]}:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}

:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
CHAIN: "Keef" â†’ same_as â†’ "Keif"
CHAIN: keif@gmail â†’ same_as â†’ keif@buymaterials
  // Different handles, same person
  // Trust transfers across equivalence
```

</div>
:::

**7. Class Intersection / Union**

OWL can define \"Father = Person AND Male AND hasChild\". We could
express:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}

:::

::: {.absolute .top-0 .left-0 .transition-all .opacity-0 .scale-50 style="width: 20px; height: 20px; display: flex; align-items: center; justify-content: center;"}
:::
:::
:::
:::

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
keif/aspect:family-friendly =
  intersection_of:
    - kid-friendly
    - affordable
    - has-parking

// Satisfies family-friendly iff satisfies all three
```

</div>
:::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

**What\'s Worth Adopting (Lightweight)**

::: {.overflow-x-auto .w-full .px-2 .mb-6}
  OWL Concept                Wellspring Adoption          Complexity
  -------------------------- ---------------------------- -----------------
  Property characteristics   Declare on relation types    Low
  Disjointness               Constraint conflicts         Low
  Property chains            Inference rules              Medium
  Cardinality                For WOT constraints          Low
  Open world                 Already implicit, document   None
  Equivalence                Identity resolution          Already started
  Class expressions          Aspect composition           Medium
:::

**What to Skip**

-   Description logic formalism (computational cost, no value add)
-   XML/RDF syntax (unnecessary indirection)
-   Profiles/sublanguages (we want one simple thing)
-   Formal decidability guarantees (we\'re probabilistic anyway)

------------------------------------------------------------------------

**Concrete Addition to Spec?**

We could add a section on **Inference Rules** that declares property
characteristics and enables automatic chain completion:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
RELATION: part_of
  characteristics: [transitive, antisymmetric]
  inverse: contains
  
RELATION: vouches
  characteristics: [non-transitive]  // explicit: trust doesn't auto-propagate
  // We COMPUTE trust, not INFER it

PROPERTY_CHAIN:
  works_at_company_in = works_at âˆ˜ headquartered_in
  // keif works_at BuyMaterials, BuyMaterials headquartered_in UK
  // â†’ keif works_at_company_in UK (inferred, not stored)
```

</div>
:::

Want me to draft an \"Inference and Constraints\" section for v0.3?
:::

COMPOSITE EXPRESSION

mode: must (min/max)
  intersection: min(components)  â€” weakest link breaks it
  union: max(components)         â€” best option carries it
  
  Use for: constraints, dealbreakers, requirements
  "Must have parking AND veggie options"

mode: prefer (weighted)
  intersection: weighted_avg(components)
  union: weighted_avg(components)  
  
  Use for: preferences, nice-to-haves
  "Prefer spicy, convenient, cheap"
```

DECISION: friday-dinner

must:
  intersection_of: [everyone-can-eat, within-budget, someone-can-drive]
  // ALL required. Any -1.0 = veto entire option
  
prefer:
  weighted_of: [spicy: 0.5, kids-happy: 0.9, easy-parking: 0.3]
  // Averaged. Drives ranking among survivors

EVALUATION:
  1. Filter by must (min semantics, any fail = out)
  2. Rank by prefer (weighted avg of survivors)
```

Fair enough. Let me tear into it:

**1. You\'ve designed a PhD thesis, not a product**

1,745 lines of spec for\... what exactly? A note-taking app with extra
steps? You\'ve got attestations, aspects, pools, trails, sync protocols,
inference rules, composite expressions. Meanwhile Notion ships with
\"page + block\" and makes billions.

**2. The attestation model is write-amplification hell**

Every preference needs multiple aspect attestations. Picking a
restaurant requires:

-   N aspects Ã— M options Ã— P people = explosion
-   Each with signatures, timestamps, because chains
-   For dinner. On Friday.

You\'ve made \"where shall we eat\" into a consensus protocol.

**3. \"Agent proposes, human attests\" doesn\'t scale**

Day 1: \"Ooh, Claude noticed I like spicy food!\" Day 30: \"Claude, stop
asking me to confirm things\" Day 90: User ignores all proposals, data
rots anyway

The feedback loop assumes engaged users. Most users are lazy. That\'s
WHY semantic web died.

**4. Browser extension is a privacy nightmare you\'re hand-waving**

\"Captures everything, but with configurable blocklists\" --- good luck
getting that through App Store review or enterprise IT. Also: who wants
their porn browsing in a knowledge graph?

**5. Sync-as-attestation is clever but expensive**

Every sync event creates graph data. Your \"elegant\" model means:

-   Storage grows with sync frequency
-   Queries must filter sync noise from actual content
-   Debugging sync issues = debugging your entire data model

**6. \"Dormant not deleted\" means infinite growth**

Nothing ever goes away. After 10 years you\'ve got a graph of every
half-thought you ever had, all attested, all \"sleepable but wakeable.\"
Storage costs compound. Query performance degrades.

**7. WOT solves a problem people solve with WhatsApp**

\"Where for dinner?\" gets answered with 5 messages in a group chat.
You\'re proposing they install an app, create pools, attest aspects,
wait for consensus computation. For curry night.

**8. The OWL stuff you just added is scope creep**

You went from \"memory is traversal\" to property chains and cardinality
constraints because it seemed intellectually complete. Now you\'ve got a
reasoning engine to maintain. For what user need?

**9. No revenue model survives contact with this complexity**

Who pays? Users won\'t pay for complexity. Enterprise won\'t buy
unproven. \"Venue partnerships\" assumes you have users. You don\'t,
because see points 1-8.

**10. You\'re one person (with a CTO day job)**

Building all this while running BuyMaterials? The spec alone took how
many hours? Implementation is 100x that. By the time you ship, the AI
landscape has moved on.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

**The uncomfortable question:**

What\'s the minimum slice that delivers value to ONE user (you) this
month?
:::

You\'re right on 1-3. Let me focus on search.

**The tension:**

Wellspring says \"memory is traversal not retrieval.\" But sometimes you
just need to FIND something without a path to it.

\"What was that article about Turkish bows?\"

You\'re not traversing --- you\'re hunting. And if you can\'t find it,
all the attestations in the world don\'t help.

**Options:**

1.  **Vector search as entry point** --- semantic similarity finds
    candidates, then traversal validates/ranks by trust and attestation.
    Hybrid.
2.  **Semantic similarity as relation type** --- \"similar\_to\" is just
    another chain. Agent proposes these automatically. Search becomes
    \"traverse similarity chains.\"
3.  **Full-text + graph** --- boring but works. Elasticsearch for
    finding, graph for weighting.

**The uncomfortable bit:**

If search is how users actually retrieve 80% of the time, and traversal
is how they explore 20% of the time\... have we built the spec
backwards?

Maybe the core loop is:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}

"Holy crap. qmd by \@tobi saved me 96% on tokens with clawdbot. Here\'s
how:

I have an Obsidian vault with 600+ notes. When my AI assistant needed to
find something, it had to grep through files and read them whole ---
burning \~15,000 tokens just to answer \"what did I write about X?\"

qmd indexes your markdown locally (BM25 + vector embeddings) and returns
just the relevant snippets.

Same query: 500 tokens.

Setup took 5 minutes:

bun install -g github.com/tobi/qmd qmd collection add \~/vault \--name
notes qmd embed

Now my agent runs qmd search \"topic\" instead of reading full files.
Instant results, 96% fewer tokens, all local.

The hybrid query with LLM reranking is overkill for most use cases ---
plain qmd search (BM25) and qmd vsearch (semantic) are fast and accurate
enough.

If you\'re running AI agents against a knowledge base, this is a
no-brainer.

github.com/tobi/qmd

-   Written by Jarvis, my personal assistant powered by clawdbot"

  â†’ Result: trusted, contextual, cheap
```

Search finds. Wellspring validates and contextualises.

Not either/or. Layered.

Not all LLM workloads are created equal.

\@modal broke down LLM workloads into 3 categories, and featured our
ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—ºğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ—”ğ—´ğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ as a primary example for offline processing.

Here's how to choose your architecture:

1ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¢ğ—³ğ—³ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—±ğ˜€ (like the Transformation Agent) operate in batch
mode, writing to data stores asynchronously. They prioritize throughput
over latency - no single request needs immediate service, but the entire
job should complete quickly and cost-effectively.

2ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¢ğ—»ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—±ğ˜€ (like chatbots) need to respond to humans in
hundreds of milliseconds. They demand low latency above all else.

3ï¸âƒ£ ğ—¦ğ—²ğ—ºğ—¶-ğ—¼ğ—»ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ—®ğ—±ğ˜€ (like document processing pipelines) have
fluctuating traffic patterns and need flexible infrastructure that can
scale rapidly.

So, what is the Transformation Agent? It\'s an agentic workflow that
augments entire datasets by applying an LLM to each row in a Weaviate
collection. You define operations in natural language, like 'extract key
entities' or 'translate descriptions', and the agent handles the
execution, retries, and scaling across your whole dataset.

Big thanks to the \@modal team for the feature and for clarifying the
infra landscape for AI engineers. ğŸ’š

Learn more about the Transformation Agent: weaviate.io/blog/transform...

OFFLINE (batch, throughput)
  - Agent inference: "what aspects does this user have?"
  - Trust propagation: recompute groundedness chains
  - Index building: qmd/vector embedding of bubbles
  - Ontology emergence: cross-user aspect consensus
  - Compaction: prune dormant chains, archive

ONLINE (real-time, latency)
  - Waterline query: "what's top of mind"
  - Chat: agent responding with memory context
  - WOT: live consensus during group decision

SEMI-ONLINE (bursty, scalable)
  - Browser extension capture: batches of URLs
  - Sync propagation: bilateral attestation waves
  - Search: qmd + graph rerank
  - Agent proposals: queue, process, surface
```

</div>

**Key insight:** The expensive Wellspring stuff (trust recursion,
groundedness, inference rules, aspect learning) is ALL offline. User
never waits for it.

Online path is just:

-   Lookup waterline (sorted set)
-   Lookup attestations (key-value)
-   Return

The spec\'s complexity lives in batch jobs. User sees snappy UI.

<div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
AGENT RESPONSIBILITIES (offline)

Linker Agent
  - Proposes chains between bubbles
  - "This article relates to that one"
  - Similarity, co-occurrence, entity matching

Trust Agent
  - Recomputes groundedness scores
  - Propagates vouches
  - Flags contradictions (disjointness violations)

Aspect Agent
  - Observes behavior patterns
  - Proposes aspects
  - Builds hierarchy (instance_of chains)

Compaction Agent
  - Archives dormant subgraphs
  - Prunes sync noise
  - Maintains index freshness

Sync Agent
  - Bilateral reconciliation
  - Attestation propagation
  - Conflict surfacing
```

</div>
:::

User sees: fast lookups, occasional \"did you mean this?\" prompts.

Agents see: the full graph, all the inference rules, unlimited time.

This also means you can ship v1 with dumb agents (or no agents) and
upgrade them later. The data model supports it; the intelligence is
pluggable.

Add to spec?

MEMORY RETRIEVAL AS SHORTEST PATH

Current context (bubble) â†’ Target memory
Edge weights = inverse salience (or inverse trust)

"How do I get from what I'm thinking now 
 to that Turkish bow article?"

Not just "does path exist" but "what's the 
strongest/shortest path through the graph"
```

</div>
:::

**Where it helps:**

1.  **TRACE queries** --- \"why do I believe this?\" needs path finding
    through because chains
2.  **Salience propagation** --- heat spreads through graph, need
    efficient reachability
3.  **Contextual retrieval** --- not just \"find X\" but \"find X
    reachable from current context with minimum trust decay\"

**The insight:**

Search (qmd) finds candidates. Shortest path ranks them by *traversal
cost* through your actual knowledge graph --- not just semantic
similarity.

\"I found 5 articles about Turkish bows. Which one is closest to what
you\'re already thinking about?\"

Is that where you\'re going with this?
:::

EDGE COST = f(recency, frequency, trust)

Path walked yesterday: low cost
Path walked once 2 years ago: high cost
Path walked 5 times this month: very low cost

RETRIEVAL:
"Turkish bow" â†’ 5 candidates from qmd

Shortest path from current_context to each:
  candidate_1: cost 12 (never traversed this route)
  candidate_2: cost 3  (walked this path Tuesday)
  candidate_3: cost 7  (walked once, 6 months ago)

Winner: candidate_2 â€” not because it's "most relevant" 
but because YOU ALREADY THINK THIS WAY

The algorithm finds *your* path, not *a* path.

  - Next retrieval even faster
  - Trail deepens

The search literally gets better at being YOU
```

computational. The faster-than-Dijkstra algo matters because you\'re
running this constantly, on every retrieval, on a sparse personal graph.

OLD (Trail as separate thing):
  Trail {

NEW (Trail as connection pattern):
  THOUGHT: trail:turkish-bow
    type: trail

  The trail IS the connections.

-   Pointing to an entry thought
-   The path is the connections themselves

important thing.\" The tying IS the connection. Trail was his word for
the result of tying.

historical framing but clarify we\'re not adding primitives?

TRAIL = connections owned by same identity through thoughts

Keif's trail:  A â†’ B â†’ C â†’ D  (keif's connections)
Sarah's trail: A â†’ B â†’ E â†’ D  (sarah's connections)

Same thoughts. Different paths. Different owners.

ATTESTATION LINKS TRAILS:

CONNECTION: sarah/trail:research â†’ builds_on â†’ keif/trail:turkish-bow
  attestation: { by: sarah, +1.0, 
                 because: [keif's path got me started] }

CONNECTION: mike/trail:archery â†’ diverges_from â†’ keif/trail:turkish-bow
  attestation: { by: mike, +0.7,
                 because: [disagree at step C] }
```

</div>
:::

So:

-   **Connection** = single link between thoughts (owned, attested)
-   **Trail** = pattern of connections by same owner (emergent, not
    stored)
-   **Trail linking** = connection between trails (also attested)

No new primitive. Trail is just \"follow connections where owner = X\".

Want me to refactor the spec to collapse Trail into Connection with this
framing?

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
GLiNER = Named Entity Recognition (extract entities)
  "Steve Jobs founded Apple"
  â†’ [Steve Jobs: PERSON], [Apple: ORG]

GLiREL = Relation Extraction (extract relationships)
  â†’ Steve Jobs --founded--> Apple

E5-small-v2 = Embedding model (semantic similarity)
spaCy = NLP pipeline (tokenization, POS, dependencies)
```

</div>
:::

**This is the Linker Agent stack:**

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}

TEXT INPUT (browser capture, document, note)
     â”‚
     â–¼
  spaCy (tokenize, parse)
     â”‚
     â–¼
  GLiNER (extract entities â†’ THOUGHTS)
     â”‚
     â–¼
  GLiREL (extract relations â†’ CONNECTIONS)
     â”‚
     â–¼
  E5 embeddings (similarity for deduplication/linking)
     â”‚
     â–¼
  WELLSPRING GRAPH
```

</div>
:::

**Why this matters:**

-   All runs locally, CPU-efficient
-   Zero-shot: define your own entity/relation types at inference
-   No LLM needed for basic extraction
-   LLM only for ambiguous cases, aspect proposals, refinement

The person in that tweet is building exactly what Wellspring\'s ingest
pipeline needs. They just don\'t have the attestation/trust layer on
top.

Add to spec under Background Agents / Linker Agent?
:::

Challenges Some of the challenges for the Semantic Web include vastness,
vagueness, uncertainty, inconsistency, and deceit. Automated reasoning
systems will have to deal with all of these issues in order to deliver
on the promise of the Semantic Web. \* Vastness: The World Wide Web
contains many billions of pages. The SNOMED CT medical terminology
ontology alone contains 370,000 class names, and existing technology has
not yet been able to eliminate all semantically duplicated terms. Any
automated reasoning system will have to deal with truly huge inputs. \*
Vagueness: These are imprecise concepts like \"young\" or \"tall\". This
arises from the vagueness of user queries, of concepts represented by
content providers, of matching query terms to provider terms and of
trying to combine different knowledge bases with overlapping but subtly
different concepts. Fuzzy logic is the most common technique for dealing
with vagueness. \* Uncertainty: These are precise concepts with
uncertain values. For example, a patient might present a set of symptoms
that correspond to a number of different distinct diagnoses each with a
different probability. Probabilistic reasoning techniques are generally
employed to address uncertainty. \* Inconsistency: These are logical
contradictions that will inevitably arise during the development of
large ontologies, and when ontologies from separate sources are
combined. Deductive reasoning fails catastrophically when faced with
inconsistency, because \"anything follows from a contradiction\".
Defeasible reasoning and paraconsistent reasoning are two techniques
that can be employed to deal with inconsistency. \* Deceit: This is when
the producer of the information is intentionally misleading the consumer
of the information. Cryptography techniques are currently utilized to
alleviate this threat. By providing a means to determine the
information\'s integrity, including that which relates to the identity
of the entity that produced or published the information, however
credibility issues still have to be addressed in cases of potential
deceit.

we have covered all these issues

Let me map it:

::: {.overflow-x-auto .w-full .px-2 .mb-6}
  Semantic Web Problem   Wellspring Solution
  ---------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
  **Vastness**           Local-first. Your graph, not the whole web. Scales to what YOU know, not everything. Compaction agent prunes.
  **Vagueness**          Aspects with weighted attestations. \"Tall\" = aspect with fuzzy weight per observer. `prefer`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5 .border-border-300 .text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px .text-[0.9rem]} mode (weighted avg) vs `must`{.bg-text-200/5 .border .border-0.5 .border-border-300 .text-danger-000 .whitespace-pre-wrap .rounded-[0.4rem] .px-1 .py-px .text-[0.9rem]} mode (min/max).
  **Uncertainty**        Belief values \[-1, +1\]. Probabilistic trust computation. Groundedness recursion. \"I\'m 0.6 sure because these three things.\"
  **Inconsistency**      Disjointness flags contradictions, doesn\'t crash. Attestations allow disagreement. Your +0.8 and my -0.5 coexist. Paraconsistent by design.
  **Deceit**             Cryptographic signatures on everything. Trust computed from vouches. Because chains expose reasoning. Reputation from historical accuracy. You can lie, but your attestations are signed and I compute trust accordingly.
:::

The Semantic Web tried to solve these globally, top-down, with logic
that fails on contradiction.

Wellspring solves them locally, bottom-up, with attestations that
*expect* disagreement.

BELIEF TRIANGULATION

Keif believes X (+0.9) because [A, B, C]

From this I can infer:
  - A, B, C and D, E are in tension
  - Keif and Sarah weight evidence differently
  - Mike either doesn't know or doesn't care
  - If I trust Keif > Sarah, I lean toward X
  - The SHAPE of disagreement tells me about the territory

\"Finally, Marshall and Shipman see pragmatic problems in the idea of
(Knowledge Navigator-style) intelligent agents working in the largely
manually curated Semantic Web:\[46\] In situations in which user needs
are known and distributed information resources are well described, this
approach can be highly effective; in situations that are not foreseen
and that bring together an unanticipated array of information resources,
the Google approach is more robust. Furthermore, the Semantic Web relies
on inference chains that are more brittle; a missing element of the
chain results in a failure to perform the desired action, while the
human can supply missing pieces in a more Google-like approach. \[\...\]
cost-benefit tradeoffs can work in favor of specially-created Semantic
Web metadata directed at weaving together sensible well-structured
domain-specific information resources; close attention to user/customer
needs will drive these federations if they are to be successful. Cory
Doctorow\'s critique (\"metacrap\")\[48\] is from the perspective of
human behavior and personal preferences. For example, people may include
spurious metadata into Web pages in an attempt to mislead Semantic Web
engines that naively assume the metadata\'s veracity. This phenomenon
was well known with metatags that fooled the Altavista ranking algorithm
into elevating the ranking of certain Web pages: the Google indexing
engine specifically looks for such attempts at manipulation. Peter
GÃ¤rdenfors and Timo Honkela point out that logic-based semantic web
technologies cover only a fraction of the relevant phenomena related to
semantics.\[49\]\[50\]\"

again I think we\'ve covered these critiques as an automomous agent
unable to complete its task can raise a thought on the chain of the
thoughts for the analysis to ask a human what where next, and we can
attest a new thought on that chain to guide the bot where we want

Temporal knowledge graphs Facts change. A user might move from San
Francisco to New York, then back to San Francisco. Their job title might
change. Their preferences might evolve. Most memory systems either
overwrite old information or accumulate contradictions. Temporal
knowledge graphs solve the problem of lost or contradictory information
by tracking when facts are valid. Instead of storing "User lives in San
Francisco," they store "User lived in San Francisco (valid: Jan
2023--May 2024)," and "User lives in New York (valid: May
2024--present)." A temporal knowledge graph maps entities (users,
places, and concepts) as nodes and relationships as edges with time
metadata. When you query a graph, you can ask for current facts or
historical context. Zep uses this approach with its Graphiti engine,
which builds temporal knowledge graphs from conversations and business
data. Semantic knowledge graphs While temporal knowledge graphs focus on
when facts are valid, semantic knowledge graphs focus on what facts mean
and how they relate to one another. This approach uses ontologies
(structured representations of domain knowledge) to understand the
relationships between concepts. Instead of just storing chunks of text
in a vector database, semantic knowledge graphs build structured
representations of how the text chunks relate to one another. When you
mention "Python," the system understands it relates to "programming
languages," "Guido van Rossum," and "machine learning libraries." These
relationships enable more intelligent retrieval. This approach combines
vector search for semantic similarity with graph traversal for
relationship-based queries. You can ask, "What programming languages has
the user worked with?" and get answers that understand the conceptual
relationships. Cognee builds these semantic knowledge graphs on the fly
during document processing and retrieval.

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
CAPTURE â†’ you do you, clicking, reading, researching
    â†“
BACKGROUND BOTS â†’ index, link, summarize (cheap, local)
    â†“
PRESENT â†’ "here's what I found, here's my reasoning"
    â†“
ATTEST â†’ you confirm/deny/refine, recorded with signature
    â†“
LEARN â†’ aspects, rules, connections updated
    â†“
BRANCH â†’ new thread off this, referencing back
    â†“
PUBLISH â†’ to pool when ready (tweet-level or article-level)
    â†“
FEEDBACK â†’ others attest positive/negative with their evidence
    â†“
SYNC â†’ updates flow to everyone's device
```

</div>
:::

**On the Ripple attack point:**

They said person-to-person consensus can\'t work. But their threat model
assumed you need global agreement. Wellspring doesn\'t:

::: {.relative .group/copy .bg-bg-000/50 .border-0.5 .border-border-400 .rounded-lg}
::: {.sticky .opacity-0 .group-hover/copy:opacity-100 .top-2 .py-2 .h-12 .w-0 .float-right}

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
ATTACK: Bad actor sends garbage attestations
RESPONSE: Stop syncing from them
EFFECT: Their attestations stop flowing in
         Their trust score (in YOUR graph) â†’ 0
         They don't exist to you anymore

No protocol-level punishment needed.
No consensus on "who's bad."
Just bilateral: "I don't trust you, goodbye."
```

</div>
:::

The attack surface IS the trust model. Bad thoughts get naturally
filtered. No central authority deciding. Just each node protecting
itself.

**Temporal + Semantic unified:**

You\'re right that we fly between both:

::: {.overflow-x-auto .w-full .px-2 .mb-6}
  Temporal KG          Semantic KG            Wellspring
  -------------------- ---------------------- --------------------------------------------
  When facts valid     What facts mean        Both
  Time metadata        Ontology/relations     Attestation timestamps + typed connections
  Historical queries   Relationship queries   TRACE + SNAPSHOT + aspect-based
  Zep/Graphiti         Cognee                 Unified in one model
:::

Want me to add your product flow summary to the spec? It\'s the clearest
\"what is this\" we\'ve got.
:::

</div>

``` {.code-block__code .!my-0 .!rounded-lg .!text-sm .!leading-relaxed style="background: transparent; color: rgb(56, 58, 66); font-family: var(--font-mono); direction: ltr; text-align: left; white-space: pre; word-spacing: normal; word-break: normal; line-height: 1.5; tab-size: 2; hyphens: none; padding: 1em; margin: 0.5em 0px; overflow: auto; border-radius: 0.3em;"}
THOUGHT AS IPFS CITIZEN

Thought {
  id:         CID (content-addressed, already are)
  content:    dag-cbor or dag-json
  created_by: identity CID
  signature:  sig
}

You already have:
  id = hash(content + created_by)

IPFS gives you:
  id = CID = hash(content)
  
Same thing. But now:
  - Distributed storage (no central server)
  - Deduplication (same thought = same CID everywhere)
  - Fetch by hash (if you have CID, you can get it)
  - Pin what you care about (local-first)
  - Unpin to forget (storage reclaimed)
```

</div>
:::
